**City Council Hears Public Comments on Voting and Housing Safety**

• Two residents spoke during the public comment period at the city council meeting

  - A speaker from the Global Intelligence Society said voters cannot check if their votes were counted correctly
  - He surveyed over 1,000 Pittsburgh residents across all nine districts and over 10,000 people nationwide
  - Found that no one can verify their vote wasn't lost, misplaced, or given to the wrong candidate
  - Called this a violation of free speech rights under the First Amendment
  - Announced plans to run for president in 2028 with vote verification as a key issue

• **Housing security problems:**
  - Yvonne Brown, who lives on Mercer Street, reported ongoing safety issues at her building
  - Said a woman named Rashida McKinley has been banned since 2020 but continues to attack residents
  - Described incidents including beating a cancer patient with a tree branch and attacking a mother and daughter with a hammer
  - Said the building manager was also physically attacked by McKinley
  - Complained that building management and County Councilman Watson have not helped resolve the situation

• **Council action:**
  - The council listened to both speakers but took no immediate action on either issue
  - Public comments are limited to matters that may come before city council for official action

summary:
• City council approved about $35,000 in invoices to pay various city departments for expenses not covered by existing contracts

• The largest single expense was $3,935 for emergency heart surgery for a police dog at Pittsburgh Veterinary Surgery

• Police department had the most expenses, including $1,575 for boarding police dogs, $2,289 for a two-month car rental, and $3,634 for updated Pennsylvania law books

• Other police costs included equipment like pepper spray for training ($332), SWAT power cartridges ($1,242), and shooting range targets ($1,634)

• The city will pay $1,500 in fines to the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission and $5,337 for traffic equipment repairs and new controllers

• Parks department will pay about $4,700 to tennis instructors for clinics and $650 to a performer for a community concert

• Smaller expenses include $50 in payments to human relations commissioners, $470 for computer troubleshooting, and various employee reimbursements for training, boots, and licenses

• The invoices passed with no discussion after a council member made a motion to approve them

headline: Pittsburgh City Council approves $583,100 grant to fund police auto theft squad detectives and equipment.
summary:
**Pittsburgh City Council approves $583,100 grant to fund police auto theft squad detectives and equipment**

• Pittsburgh City Council approved a resolution allowing the city to receive up to $583,100 from the Pennsylvania Auto Theft Prevention Agency to support the police Auto Squad

• The grant money, funded by insurance companies, will pay for detective salaries, overtime, equipment, and vehicles for the auto theft unit

• Council members questioned police leadership about past problems with the grant program, including money sitting unused and staffing issues that led to a detective leaving the department

• Acting Police Chief Morgan Devine said the department now has two detectives working in the auto theft unit after previously being down to just one officer

• The grant requires the city to follow regular spending rules and deposit the money into a specific grants account

• Police officials said most car thefts in Pittsburgh are committed by young people taking cars for joyrides, not organized crime groups running chop shops

• The department previously issued public warnings about Hyundai and Kia vehicles being easier targets for theft and provided steering wheel locks to help prevent break-ins

• Council members praised the acting chief for improving department morale and fixing problems with the grant program

headline: Pittsburgh City Council approves $30,000 contract to buy three police dogs over three years from German Shepherd breeder.
summary:
**Pittsburgh City Council Approves $30,000 for Police Dogs**

• Pittsburgh City Council approved a contract with Von der Haus Gill German Shepherds Inc. to buy police dogs for up to $30,000 over three years

• The money will be spread out evenly - $10,000 per year from 2025 to 2027

• Each police dog costs about $9,500, so the contract could buy up to three dogs during the three-year period

• Pittsburgh police currently have 15 working dogs that serve different purposes:
  - 6 dogs that detect explosives
  - 5 dogs that find illegal drugs  
  - 1 bloodhound for finding missing people
  - 1 dog trained to find hidden electronics like cell phones and hard drives

• Police Sergeant Kyle Nelson said the dogs work every day and are available 24 hours a day when needed

• Council members praised how police dogs and horses help build better relationships between officers and children in neighborhoods

• The contract still needs approval from the city's legal department before it becomes final

• The bill had been delayed for some time while city officials worked out the details with the Office of Management and Budget
